document_validation.reason: Document outlines governance structure overseeing customer experience, product oversight, and regulatory compliance, which directly relates to CPC requirements.

This document is relevant for CPC regulation comparison as it outlines the Fit and Proper Policy for Saol Assurance, which directly relates to governance and oversight structures that impact regulatory compliance. The policy ensures that persons in key functions meet fitness and probity standards required by the Central Bank of Ireland, which is fundamental to proper governance and ultimately affects customer protection. The document references compliance with the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards and the Central Bank Reform Act, which are part of the regulatory framework that supports consumer protection. While not explicitly focused on customer interactions, the proper vetting and qualification of key personnel is a critical foundation for ensuring appropriate customer treatment and regulatory compliance.
document_validation.document_name: Saol InsureCo and HoldCo Fit and Proper Policy V6 approved 2025.pdf

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: The ExCo also ensures that the Company maintains a strong risk and control environment, that the relevant regulatory requirements are complied with and promotes a high standard of conduct throughout the business.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Scope and application
detailed_results.regulation_text:
2. (1) Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3), these Regulations apply to a 
regulated entity in the conduct of its affairs.     
(2) These Regulations do not apply to a regulated entity insofar as it engages 
in one or more of the following:  
(a) any service or activity set out in the Schedule 1 to the  MiFID 
Regulations 2017, but not including any service or activity of a 
person to whom such Regulations do not apply by virtue of 
Regulation 4(3) of the MiFID Regulations 2017 ; 
(b) credit union activities, other than when the credit union is acting 
as an insurance intermediary;  
(c) the activities of a Crowdfunding Service Provider, within the 
meaning of Regulation 2(1) of Regulation (EU) 2020/1503 of the 
European Parliament and of the Council of 7 October 2020 on 
European crowdfunding service providers for business, and 
amending Regu lation (EU) 2017/1129 and Directive (EU) 
2019/1937;  
(d) reinsurance business.  
(3) Regulation 4(1)(a), Regulation 4(1)(f), Regulation 5 and Regulation 10, 
apply only in respect of a customer who is a consume r. 
 
  
Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
"Iris Oifigiúil" of 25th March , 2025 .

detailed_results.gap_description: While the document acknowledges regulatory compliance in general, it does not specifically reference the CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025 or demonstrate awareness of the specific definitions in Regulation 3. The document refers to 'AIB JV DAC' as 'the Company' but doesn't clarify if it falls under the definition of a 'regulated entity' as defined in the regulation. Additionally, there's no explicit mention of how the company handles customer relationships in accordance with the regulatory definitions of 'customer' and 'consumer'.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Update the Terms of Reference to explicitly reference compliance with the CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025. 2. Include specific language acknowledging the company's status as a 'regulated entity' if applicable. 3. Add definitions section that aligns with regulatory definitions of key terms like 'customer' and 'consumer'. 4. Incorporate specific responsibilities for the ExCo regarding oversight of compliance with these regulations. 5. Ensure the document's next review (scheduled for September 2025) includes assessment against the 2025 regulations.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Definitions
detailed_results.regulation_text:
3. (1) In these Regulations - 
“Act of 2010” means the Central Bank Reform Act 2010 (No.  23 of 2010);  
“Bank” means the Central Bank of Ireland;  
“consumer”  means , subject to paragraph (3), a customer that is - 
(a) a natural person,  
(b) a group of natural persons, including a partnership, club, charity, 
trust or other unincorporated body, or  
(c) an incorporated body, that is not –  
(i) an incorporated body that had an annual turnover in excess 
of €5 million in the previous financial year, or  
(ii) an incorporated body that is a member of a group of 
companies having a combined turnover greater than €5 
million;  
 “customer”  means , subject to paragraph (2) - 
(a) any person to whom a regulated entity provides or offers financial 
services,  
(b) any person who requests the provision of financial services from 
the regulated entity,  
(c) a relevant borrower in a case where a regulated entity undertakes 
credit servicing in respect of the credit agreement concerned, or  
(d) a hirer in a case where a regulated entity undertakes credit 
servicing in respect of the consumer -hire agreement or hire -
purchase agreement concerned,  
and shall include, where appropriate, a potential “customer” and former 
“customer” within the meaning above;  
“financial abuse” means any of the following:  
(a) the wrongful or unauthorised taking, withholding, appropriation, 
or use of a customer’s money, assets or property;  
(b) any act or omission by a person, including through the use of a 
power of attorney, guardianship, or any other authority regarding 
a customer, to –  
(i) obtain control, through deception, intimidation or undue 
influence, over the customer’s money, assets or property, or  
(ii) wrongfully interfere with or deny the customer’s 
ownership, use, benefit or possession of the customer’s 
money, assets or property;  
“financial services ” include financial products ; 
“group” includes, unless otherwise specified, a company, its parent and its 
subsidiaries and any associated undertaking or related undertaking;  
4  [80] 
“high cost credit provider” and “high cost credit” have the meaning assigned to 
them in section 2 of the Consumer Credit Act 1995 (No. 24 of 1995);  
“key information” means any information which is likely to influence a 
customer’s actions with regard to a financial service;  
“MiFID Regulations 2017” means the European Union (Markets in Financial 
Instruments) Regulations 2017 (S.I. No. 375 of 2017);  
“person” means, unless otherwise specified, a natural person or a legal person;  
"regulated activities" means the provision of financial services that are provided 
in the State by a regulated entity and which are subject to the regulation of the 
Bank and a “regulated activity” is the provision of any one such financial service;  
“regulated entity” means a financial services provider authorised, registered or 
licensed by -   
(a) the Bank,  
(b) a state (other than the State) that is a member of the European 
Union,  or  
(c) a state (other than the State) that is a contracting party to the 
Agreement on the European Economic Area signed at Oporto on 
2 May 1992, as adjusted by all subsequent amendments to that 
agreement,  
that is providing regulated activities in the State;  
“unregulated activities” means the provision of services of a financial nature, 
which are not otherwise regulated activities, to consumers in the State.  
(2) For the purposes of the definition of “customer” in paragraph (1), 
“relevant borrower”, “credit servicing”, “credit agreement”, “consumer -hire 
agreement”, “hire -purchase agreement” and “hirer” have the same meaning as 
in Part V of the Central Bank Act 1997  (No. 8 of 1997).  
(3) Where a high cost credit provider is engaged in the activity of providing 
high cost credit, “consumer” means a consumer within the meaning of the 
Consumer Credit Act 1995.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Acting with honesty and integrity
detailed_results.regulation_text:
6. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(b), a regulated 
entity shall act honestly and with integrity, including by:  
(a) operating without bias and preventing, or identifying and 
appropriately managing, conflicts of interest;  
(b) not exerting pressure or influence on a customer so as to limit his 
or her ability to make an informed choice in relation to any 
financial service;  
(c) not misusing or misappropriating any assets or information of the 
regulated entity  or its customers.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: The ExCo also ensures that the Company maintains a strong risk and control environment, that the relevant regulatory requirements are complied with and promotes a high standard of conduct throughout the business.
detailed_results.gap_description: While the document mentions compliance with regulatory requirements and promoting high standards of conduct, it lacks specific provisions addressing how the Executive Committee will ensure customer interests are secured as required by Regulation 5. The document does not explicitly mention customer interests, fair outcomes for customers, complaint resolution processes, or error handling procedures that are specifically required under Regulation 5.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Add specific provisions in the Terms of Reference that explicitly address securing customers' interests in line with Regulation 5. 2. Include responsibilities for the ExCo to oversee customer complaint resolution processes. 3. Add provisions for the ExCo to monitor and ensure fair outcomes for customers. 4. Include oversight of error identification and resolution processes affecting customers. 5. Add specific reference to the CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025 to demonstrate awareness of and commitment to compliance with these regulations.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Securing customers' interests
detailed_results.regulation_text:
5. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(a), a regulated 
entity shall secure its customers’ interests, including by:  
(a) ensuring that its culture, strategy, business model, decision -
making, systems, controls, policies, processes and procedures 
take into account its customers’ interests;  
(b) acting in accordance with the reasonable expectations of its 
customers;  
(c) taking into account the interests of its customers when designing 
financial services, and the methods of delivery;  
(d) ensuring that its financial  services are not designed to unfairly 
exploit the behaviours, habits, preferences or biases of customers 
leading to customer detriment;  
(e) resolving any complaints received from customers efficiently, 
fairly and in a timely manner;  
(f) resolving errors and mistakes affecting customers efficiently, 
fairly and in a timely manner, and disclosing errors and mistakes 
to customers affected in a timely manner;  
(g) ensuring errors and mistakes identified for one customer that may 
reasonably have affected other customers are resolved for all 
affected customers efficiently, fairly and in a timely manner;  
(h) clearly distinguishing for customers between the entity’s 
regulated activities and its unregulated activities including by 
taking all appropriate steps to mitigate the risk that a customer 
6  [80] 
will understand an activity to be, or to carry the protections of, a 
regulated activity where this is not the case;  
(i) delivering fair outcomes for customers.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: The ExCo is made up of a small group of senior business leaders who support the CEO in driving the business forward through constructive challenge and collaborations. It focuses on strategic leadership, management and direction and ensuring the most effective prioritisation of resources. The ExCo also ensures that the Company maintains a strong risk and control environment, that the relevant regulatory requirements are complied with and promotes a high standard of conduct throughout the business.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Acting with due skill, care and diligence
detailed_results.regulation_text:
7. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(c), a regulated 
entity shall act with due skill, care and diligence, including by:  
(a) ensuring that persons who are responsible for managing the 
activities of the regulated entity have appropriate knowledge of 
the activities and associated risks that apply in the conduct of its 
affairs;  
(b) complying with all financial services legislation applicable to the 
conduct of its affairs;  
(c) operating in compliance with standards of market conduct and 
trading venue rules to which the regulated entity is subject by law 
and any market codes that apply to the affairs of the regulated 
entity.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: The role of the Executive Committee ("ExCo" or the "Committee") is to assist the CEO in overseeing AIB JV DAC's (or the "Company's") overall performance and delivery. The ExCo is made up of a small group of senior business leaders who support the CEO in driving the business forward through constructive challenge and collaborations. It focuses on strategic leadership, management and direction and ensuring the most effective prioritisation of resources. The ExCo also ensures that the Company maintains a strong risk and control environment, that the relevant regulatory requirements are complied with and promotes a high standard of conduct throughout the business.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Controlling and managing its affairs
detailed_results.regulation_text:
11. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(g), a regulated 
entity shall control and manage its affairs and systems sustainably, responsibly 
and in a sound and prudent manner, including by:  
(a) having and employing appropriate resources and implementing 
effective governance of  policies and procedures, systems and 
control checks, including compliance checks, to ensure that the 
regulated entity complies with its obligations under financial 
service s legislation;  
(b) providing appropriate staff training on the legal and regulatory 
framework relevant to the performance of those functions, 
including any legal obligations or standards that are imposed by 
or under financial services legislation;  
(c) ensuring that if delegating tasks, that those tasks are assigned to 
an appropriate person with effective oversight within the 
regulated entity;  
(d) managing its outsourced activities effectively to identify, monitor 
and manage its outsourcing risk;  
(e) arranging adequate protection for assets held by the regulated 
entity on behalf of a customer.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Controlling and managing its affairs
detailed_results.regulation_text:
11. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(g), a regulated 
entity shall control and manage its affairs and systems sustainably, responsibly 
and in a sound and prudent manner, including by:  
(a) having and employing appropriate resources and implementing 
effective governance of  policies and procedures, systems and 
control checks, including compliance checks, to ensure that the 
regulated entity complies with its obligations under financial 
service s legislation;  
(b) providing appropriate staff training on the legal and regulatory 
framework relevant to the performance of those functions, 
including any legal obligations or standards that are imposed by 
or under financial services legislation;  
(c) ensuring that if delegating tasks, that those tasks are assigned to 
an appropriate person with effective oversight within the 
regulated entity;  
(d) managing its outsourced activities effectively to identify, monitor 
and manage its outsourcing risk;  
(e) arranging adequate protection for assets held by the regulated 
entity on behalf of a customer.

detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Update section 9 on 'Conflicts of interest' to explicitly address the conflicts mentioned in Regulation 23, specifically regarding fees, commissions, rewards, or remuneration linked to targets that might not consider consumers' best interests. 2. Include specific provisions prohibiting agreements where the entity receives rewards in the form of goods or services in return for directing business through another person. 3. Develop and document a process for identifying, managing, and avoiding such conflicts. 4. Ensure the ExCo's oversight responsibilities explicitly include monitoring for these specific types of conflicts.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Certain conflicts of interest that are to be avoided
detailed_results.regulation_text: 23. A regulated entity shall avoid conflicts of interest relating to the following: (a) fees, commission, other rewards or remuneration linked to the achievement of targets that do not consider a consumer 's best interests, including targets relating to volume (including override commission) and bonus payments linked to business retention; (b) agreements under which the regulated entity receives a fee, commission, other reward or remuneration in the form of goods or services, in return for which it agrees to direct business through or in the way of another person.

detailed_results.gap_recommendations: The document should be expanded to include a comprehensive conflicts of interest policy that: 1) Clearly identifies circumstances that constitute or may give rise to conflicts of interest with respect to consumers, 2) Specifies detailed procedures to follow and measures to adopt for identifying and managing conflicts, 3) Explicitly states how the policy is appropriate to the nature, scale and complexity of SAOL Assurance DAC's regulated activities, and 4) References how the policy will be maintained and adhered to by the organization.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Conflicts of interest policy to be in place
detailed_results.regulation_text: 22. (1) A regulated entity shall establish, maintain and adhere to a robust conflicts of interest policy appropriate to the nature, scale and complexity of the regulated activities carried out by the regulated entity. (2) The conflicts of interest policy referred to in paragraph (1) shall with reference to its regulated activities - (a) identify the circumstances which constitute, or may give rise to, a conflict of interest with respect to its consumers, including those conflicts that are the subject of Regulation 23, and (b) specify procedures to be followed, and measures to be adopted, to properly identify and manage any conflicts identified, excluding those conflicts that are the subject of the obligation referred to in Regulation 23 and which therefore must be avoided.

detailed_results.gap_description: While the document mentions 'Conflicts of interest' in its table of contents (section 9), the provided excerpt doesn't contain the full content of this section. The document lacks specific details on how conflicts of interest with consumers are managed, including: (1) disclosure of conflicts to consumers in writing, (2) obtaining consumer acknowledgment on paper or durable medium, and (3) steps to manage conflicts and minimize impact on consumers as required by Regulation 24(3).
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: Update section 9 'Conflicts of interest' to include specific procedures that align with Regulation 24, particularly: (1) A process for written disclosure of conflicts to consumers, (2) A requirement to obtain consumer acknowledgment in writing or another durable medium, (3) Clear steps for managing conflicts and minimizing their impact on consumers, and (4) Circumstances when services cannot be provided due to conflicts that cannot be managed.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Steps in respect of conflicts of interest that may be managed
detailed_results.regulation_text: 24. (1) This Regulation does not apply to conflicts of interest that are the subject of Regulation 23 on the basis that those conflicts are required to be avoided pursuant to that Regulation and there are no circumstances in which such conflicts are permitted to b e managed pursuant to paragraphs (2) and (3). (2) Where a conflict of interest arises with respect to a consumer and cannot be reasonably avoided, a regulated entity shall - (a) disclose the nature and source of the conflict of interest to the consumer, and (b) ensure that the conflict does not result in any damage to the interests of that consumer. (3) For the purposes of this Regulation, a regulated entity may not provide a regulated activity to a consumer if a conflict arises directly or indirectly unless - (a) the regulated entity has fully and transparently disclosed the existence and details of the conflict in writing, (b) the consumer has acknowledged, on paper or on another durable medium, that he or she understands the conflict and wishes to proceed, and (c) the regulated entity has taken all steps within its control to appropriately manage the conflict and minimise the impact of the conflict on the consumer.
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025

The document lacks explicit procedures for maintaining information barriers, handling breaches of information barriers, and notifying relevant officers and employees of these procedures as required by Regulation 28.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Add a specific section on information barriers that defines them in line with Regulation 28(4). 2. Include procedures for establishing and maintaining effective information barriers between different employees, business areas, and connected parties. 3. Detail procedures for handling breaches of information barriers. 4. Specify how these procedures will be communicated to relevant officers and employees. 5. Consider adding this to section 9 (Conflicts of interest) or as a new dedicated section.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Information barriers to be put in place
detailed_results.regulation_text: 28. (1) A regulated entity shall put in place effective information barriers between different employees and business areas of the regulated entity, and between the regulated entity and its connected parties, in relation to information which could give rise to a c onflict of interest with consumers. (2) A regulated entity shall establish, maintain and adhere to procedures relating to the robust maintenance of information barriers and the consequences for and handling of breaches of information barriers. (3) A regulated entity shall notify the procedures referred to in paragraph (2) to officers and employees of the regulated entity for whom the procedures are relevant. (4) In this Regulation, "information barriers" means an arrangement within the regulated entity, or between the regulated entity and any associate of that regulated entity, which requires information held, or the fact of information held by the regulated entit y, or as the case may be, any associate of that regulated entity, or a particular operating unit within the regulated entity or within any associate of that regulated entity in the course of carrying on one part of its business of any kind, to be withh eld and properly segregated in certain circumstances from other operating units or from persons with whom it deals in the course of carrying on another part of its business of any kind in order to preserve the confidentiality of the information and avoid a potential conflict of interests.

detailed_results.gap_description: While the document mentions maintaining a strong risk and control environment and complying with regulatory requirements in general, it lacks specific written procedures for the handling of errors affecting consumers as required by Regulation 96. The document does not detail: (1) procedures for identifying causes and impacts of errors on consumers, (2) identifying affected consumers, (3) timely detection and escalation of significant errors, (4) control of correction processes, (5) oversight of error handling, (6) regular analysis of error patterns, and (7) reporting arrangements for errors to compliance/risk functions and the board.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Add a specific section on error handling governance that addresses all requirements of Regulation 96, including procedures for identifying, escalating, and correcting errors affecting consumers. 2. Include provisions for regular analysis (at least semi-annual) of error patterns and causes. 3. Establish clear reporting lines for errors to compliance/risk functions and the board. 4. Define what constitutes a 'significant error' requiring urgent escalation. 5. Document the oversight arrangements for error handling processes.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Robust governance arrangements required for errors handling
detailed_results.regulation_text: 96. (1) A regulated entity shall have in place robust governance arrangements, including written procedures, for the appropriate and effective handling of errors that affect consumers. (2) The arrangements referred to in paragraph (1) shall include the following: (a) at a minimum, provision for - (i) identification of the cause and potential impact of the error on consumers, (ii) identification of all potentially affected consumers, (iii) the timely detection, classification and urgent escalation to the board of directors, or the entity or persons controlling the regulated entity, of errors of such scale and significance as would reasonably be termed significant errors that affect consumers, and of a nature that such management ought to be made aware of, and (iv) proper control of the correction process; (b) arrangements for the proper oversight of the handling of errors; (c) analysis at the appropriate level of the rate of occurrence and patterns of errors, to include the causes of same, on a regular basis and, in that regard, at least once every 6 months; (d) arrangements within the regulated entity for reporting to the compliance or risk function of the regulated entity, or any other relevant function of the regulated entity as required, as well as to the board of directors, or the entity or persons contro lling the regulated entity, of aggregated information on the number of errors handled and the number of such errors that have been resolved, and on the analysis referred to in subparagraph (c).
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025

The document does not explicitly mention: (1) processes for proper oversight of complaints handling, (2) regular analysis (at least once every 6 months) of complaints patterns and rates, including those resolved within 5 working days, and (3) arrangements for reporting complaints data to compliance/risk functions and the board.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: Update the Terms of Reference to include specific provisions for complaints handling governance, including: (1) Define explicit processes for oversight of complaints handling, (2) Establish requirements for analyzing complaints data at least once every 6 months, including tracking complaints resolved within 5 working days, (3) Formalize reporting arrangements for complaints data to relevant functions and the board, (4) Consider creating a dedicated section on consumer protection and complaints handling within the document.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Governance arrangements for complaints handling
detailed_results.regulation_text: 107. (1) A regulated entity shall implement robust governance arrangements for the appropriate handling of complaints from consumers. (2) The arrangements referred to in paragraph (1) shall include - (a) processes for the proper oversight of complaints handling, (b) analysis on a regular basis and, in that regard, at least once every 6 months, of the rate of occurrence and patterns of complaints, which shall include complaints resolved within 5 working days, and (c) arrangements within the regulated entity for reporting to the compliance or risk function of the regulated entity, or any other relevant function of the regulated entity as required, as well as to the board of directors, or the entity or persons contro lling the regulated entity, of aggregated information on the number of complaints handled and resolved, and on the analysis referred to in subparagraph (b). compliance_analysis.document_name: Saol InsureCo and HoldCo Fit and Proper Policy V6 approved 2025.pdf

detailed_results.compliance_evidence:
Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Definitions
detailed_results.regulation_text:
3. (1) In these Regulations - 
“Act of 2010” means the Central Bank Reform Act 2010 (No.  23 of 2010);  
“Bank” means the Central Bank of Ireland;  
“consumer”  means , subject to paragraph (3), a customer that is - 
(a) a natural person,  
(b) a group of natural persons, including a partnership, club, charity, 
trust or other unincorporated body, or  
(c) an incorporated body, that is not –  
(i) an incorporated body that had an annual turnover in excess 
of €5 million in the previous financial year, or  
(ii) an incorporated body that is a member of a group of 
companies having a combined turnover greater than €5 
million;  
 “customer”  means , subject to paragraph (2) - 
(a) any person to whom a regulated entity provides or offers financial 
services,  
(b) any person who requests the provision of financial services from 
the regulated entity,  
(c) a relevant borrower in a case where a regulated entity undertakes 
credit servicing in respect of the credit agreement concerned, or  
(d) a hirer in a case where a regulated entity undertakes credit 
servicing in respect of the consumer -hire agreement or hire -
purchase agreement concerned,  
and shall include, where appropriate, a potential “customer” and former 
“customer” within the meaning above;  
“financial abuse” means any of the following:  
(a) the wrongful or unauthorised taking, withholding, appropriation, 
or use of a customer’s money, assets or property;  
(b) any act or omission by a person, including through the use of a 
power of attorney, guardianship, or any other authority regarding 
a customer, to –  
(i) obtain control, through deception, intimidation or undue 
influence, over the customer’s money, assets or property, or  
(ii) wrongfully interfere with or deny the customer’s 
ownership, use, benefit or possession of the customer’s 
money, assets or property;  
“financial services ” include financial products ; 
“group” includes, unless otherwise specified, a company, its parent and its 
subsidiaries and any associated undertaking or related undertaking;  
4  [80] 
“high cost credit provider” and “high cost credit” have the meaning assigned to 
them in section 2 of the Consumer Credit Act 1995 (No. 24 of 1995);  
“key information” means any information which is likely to influence a 
customer’s actions with regard to a financial service;  
“MiFID Regulations 2017” means the European Union (Markets in Financial 
Instruments) Regulations 2017 (S.I. No. 375 of 2017);  
“person” means, unless otherwise specified, a natural person or a legal person;  
"regulated activities" means the provision of financial services that are provided 
in the State by a regulated entity and which are subject to the regulation of the 
Bank and a “regulated activity” is the provision of any one such financial service;  
“regulated entity” means a financial services provider authorised, registered or 
licensed by -   
(a) the Bank,  
(b) a state (other than the State) that is a member of the European 
Union,  or  
(c) a state (other than the State) that is a contracting party to the 
Agreement on the European Economic Area signed at Oporto on 
2 May 1992, as adjusted by all subsequent amendments to that 
agreement,  
that is providing regulated activities in the State;  
“unregulated activities” means the provision of services of a financial nature, 
which are not otherwise regulated activities, to consumers in the State.  
(2) For the purposes of the definition of “customer” in paragraph (1), 
“relevant borrower”, “credit servicing”, “credit agreement”, “consumer -hire 
agreement”, “hire -purchase agreement” and “hirer” have the same meaning as 
in Part V of the Central Bank Act 1997  (No. 8 of 1997).  
(3) Where a high cost credit provider is engaged in the activity of providing 
high cost credit, “consumer” means a consumer within the meaning of the 
Consumer Credit Act 1995.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Scope and application
detailed_results.regulation_text:
2. (1) Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3), these Regulations apply to a 
regulated entity in the conduct of its affairs.     
(2) These Regulations do not apply to a regulated entity insofar as it engages 
in one or more of the following:  
(a) any service or activity set out in the Schedule 1 to the  MiFID 
Regulations 2017, but not including any service or activity of a 
person to whom such Regulations do not apply by virtue of 
Regulation 4(3) of the MiFID Regulations 2017 ; 
(b) credit union activities, other than when the credit union is acting 
as an insurance intermediary;  
(c) the activities of a Crowdfunding Service Provider, within the 
meaning of Regulation 2(1) of Regulation (EU) 2020/1503 of the 
European Parliament and of the Council of 7 October 2020 on 
European crowdfunding service providers for business, and 
amending Regu lation (EU) 2017/1129 and Directive (EU) 
2019/1937;  
(d) reinsurance business.  
(3) Regulation 4(1)(a), Regulation 4(1)(f), Regulation 5 and Regulation 10, 
apply only in respect of a customer who is a consume r. 
 
  
Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
"Iris Oifigiúil" of 25th March , 2025 .

detailed_results.compliance_evidence_with_page:
[Page 3] Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence:
Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.
detailed_results.gap_description: The document focuses primarily on fitness and probity standards for individuals but does not explicitly address all elements of the 2025 Standards for Business regulation, particularly regarding: (1) securing customers' interests, (2) ensuring information is presented effectively to customers, (3) controlling risks of financial abuse to customers, and (4) managing affairs sustainably. While the document establishes a framework for ensuring proper governance through fit and proper individuals, it lacks direct references to the specific requirements in Regulation 4(1) of the 2025 Standards.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations:
1. Update the policy to explicitly reference the CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025.
2. Add specific sections addressing how the fit and proper assessment contributes to securing customers' interests.
3. Include provisions on how the company ensures information is presented effectively to customers.
4. Add requirements for controlling and managing risks of financial abuse to customers.
5. Incorporate language on sustainable and responsible management of affairs and systems.
6. Create a compliance matrix showing how the fit and proper policy aligns with each element of Regulation 4(1).

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").
detailed_results.gap_description: While the document addresses fitness and probity requirements, it does not explicitly address how the company will secure customers' interests as required by Regulation 5. The policy focuses on internal governance for fit and proper assessments but lacks specific provisions for ensuring the company's culture, strategy, business model, and decision-making take customers' interests into account. It also doesn't address how the company will act in accordance with customers' reasonable expectations, design financial services with customers' interests in mind, avoid exploiting customer behaviors, resolve complaints efficiently, handle errors, or deliver fair outcomes for customers.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: The Fit and Proper Policy should be expanded to include specific provisions that address how the fitness and probity requirements contribute to securing customers' interests. This should include: 1) Adding a section on how fit and proper assessments ensure that key personnel will act in customers' interests; 2) Incorporating customer-centric criteria in the fitness assessment; 3) Adding provisions about how the company's culture and decision-making processes take customers' interests into account; 4) Including requirements for resolving customer complaints and errors efficiently and fairly; 5) Adding provisions about designing financial services with customers' interests in mind; and 6) Establishing metrics to measure fair customer outcomes.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Securing customers' interests
detailed_results.regulation_text:
5. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(a), a regulated 
entity shall secure its customers’ interests, including by:  
(a) ensuring that its culture, strategy, business model, decision -
making, systems, controls, policies, processes and procedures 
take into account its customers’ interests;  
(b) acting in accordance with the reasonable expectations of its 
customers;  
(c) taking into account the interests of its customers when designing 
financial services, and the methods of delivery;  
(d) ensuring that its financial  services are not designed to unfairly 
exploit the behaviours, habits, preferences or biases of customers 
leading to customer detriment;  
(e) resolving any complaints received from customers efficiently, 
fairly and in a timely manner;  
(f) resolving errors and mistakes affecting customers efficiently, 
fairly and in a timely manner, and disclosing errors and mistakes 
to customers affected in a timely manner;  
(g) ensuring errors and mistakes identified for one customer that may 
reasonably have affected other customers are resolved for all 
affected customers efficiently, fairly and in a timely manner;  
(h) clearly distinguishing for customers between the entity’s 
regulated activities and its unregulated activities including by 
taking all appropriate steps to mitigate the risk that a customer 
6  [80] 
will understand an activity to be, or to carry the protections of, a 
regulated activity where this is not the case;  
(i) delivering fair outcomes for customers.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Acting with due skill, care and diligence
detailed_results.regulation_text:
7. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(c), a regulated 
entity shall act with due skill, care and diligence, including by:  
(a) ensuring that persons who are responsible for managing the 
activities of the regulated entity have appropriate knowledge of 
the activities and associated risks that apply in the conduct of its 
affairs;  
(b) complying with all financial services legislation applicable to the 
conduct of its affairs;  
(c) operating in compliance with standards of market conduct and 
trading venue rules to which the regulated entity is subject by law 
and any market codes that apply to the affairs of the regulated 
entity.

detailed_results.gap_description: While the document acknowledges the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards and mentions acting with integrity in general terms, it does not explicitly address all elements of Regulation 6, particularly regarding: (a) operating without bias and managing conflicts of interest; (b) not exerting pressure on customers; and (c) not misusing assets or information of the entity or customers. The document focuses on fitness and probity of individuals but lacks specific provisions about how the entity itself will act with honesty and integrity in accordance with the 2025 Standards for Business regulations.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Update the policy to explicitly incorporate the requirements of Regulation 6 of the 2025 Standards for Business, including specific provisions about operating without bias, managing conflicts of interest, not exerting pressure on customers, and not misusing assets or information. 2. Add a dedicated section on how the entity will ensure compliance with the Standards for Business Regulations 2025, particularly regarding acting with honesty and integrity. 3. Include specific procedures for identifying and managing conflicts of interest at the entity level, not just at the individual level. 4. Develop clear guidelines on customer interactions to prevent undue pressure or influence. 5. Establish protocols for safeguarding customer and company assets and information.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Acting with honesty and integrity
detailed_results.regulation_text:
6. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(b), a regulated 
entity shall act honestly and with integrity, including by:  
(a) operating without bias and preventing, or identifying and 
appropriately managing, conflicts of interest;  
(b) not exerting pressure or influence on a customer so as to limit his 
or her ability to make an informed choice in relation to any 
financial service;  
(c) not misusing or misappropriating any assets or information of the 
regulated entity  or its customers.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Financial abuse
detailed_results.regulation_text:
10. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(f), a regulated 
entity shall control and manage it affairs and systems to counter the risks of 
financial abuse to customers to whom it is providing financial services within 
the scope of its regulated activities, including by:  
(a) putting reasonable systems and controls in place in the context of 
the provision of its financial services, to mitigate the risk to its 
customers of financial abuse;  
(b) appropriately monitoring financial abuse trends relevant to its 
customers or the sector more generally;  
(c) carrying out ongoing monitoring in respect of potential 
vulnerabilities in the services and distribution channels, and 
ensuring appropriate escalation processes where there is 
increased risk to its customers of financial abuse;  
(d) notifying its customers through clear and timely communication 
of any digital frauds or deception connected to its affairs, or 
8  [80] 
specifically relevant to the sector in which the regulated entity is 
operating, and of which it is aware;  
(e) communicating the supports available to its customers, and the 
actions that customers can take in the event of financial abuse, 
directly connected to the regulated entity’s affairs.

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Controlling and managing its affairs
detailed_results.regulation_text:
11. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(g), a regulated 
entity shall control and manage its affairs and systems sustainably, responsibly 
and in a sound and prudent manner, including by:  
(a) having and employing appropriate resources and implementing 
effective governance of  policies and procedures, systems and 
control checks, including compliance checks, to ensure that the 
regulated entity complies with its obligations under financial 
service s legislation;  
(b) providing appropriate staff training on the legal and regulatory 
framework relevant to the performance of those functions, 
including any legal obligations or standards that are imposed by 
or under financial services legislation;  
(c) ensuring that if delegating tasks, that those tasks are assigned to 
an appropriate person with effective oversight within the 
regulated entity;  
(d) managing its outsourced activities effectively to identify, monitor 
and manage its outsourcing risk;  
(e) arranging adequate protection for assets held by the regulated 
entity on behalf of a customer.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Scope and application
detailed_results.regulation_text:
2. (1) Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3), these Regulations apply to a 
regulated entity in the conduct of its affairs.     
(2) These Regulations do not apply to a regulated entity insofar as it engages 
in one or more of the following:  
(a) any service or activity set out in the Schedule 1 to the  MiFID 
Regulations 2017, but not including any service or activity of a 
person to whom such Regulations do not apply by virtue of 
Regulation 4(3) of the MiFID Regulations 2017 ; 
(b) credit union activities, other than when the credit union is acting 
as an insurance intermediary;  
(c) the activities of a Crowdfunding Service Provider, within the 
meaning of Regulation 2(1) of Regulation (EU) 2020/1503 of the 
European Parliament and of the Council of 7 October 2020 on 
European crowdfunding service providers for business, and 
amending Regu lation (EU) 2017/1129 and Directive (EU) 
2019/1937;  
(d) reinsurance business.  
(3) Regulation 4(1)(a), Regulation 4(1)(f), Regulation 5 and Regulation 10, 
apply only in respect of a customer who is a consume r. 
 
  
Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
"Iris Oifigiúil" of 25th March , 2025 .

detailed_results.regulation_title: Definitions
detailed_results.regulation_text:
3. (1) In these Regulations - 
“Act of 2010” means the Central Bank Reform Act 2010 (No.  23 of 2010);  
“Bank” means the Central Bank of Ireland;  
“consumer”  means , subject to paragraph (3), a customer that is - 
(a) a natural person,  
(b) a group of natural persons, including a partnership, club, charity, 
trust or other unincorporated body, or  
(c) an incorporated body, that is not –  
(i) an incorporated body that had an annual turnover in excess 
of €5 million in the previous financial year, or  
(ii) an incorporated body that is a member of a group of 
companies having a combined turnover greater than €5 
million;  
 “customer”  means , subject to paragraph (2) - 
(a) any person to whom a regulated entity provides or offers financial 
services,  
(b) any person who requests the provision of financial services from 
the regulated entity,  
(c) a relevant borrower in a case where a regulated entity undertakes 
credit servicing in respect of the credit agreement concerned, or  
(d) a hirer in a case where a regulated entity undertakes credit 
servicing in respect of the consumer -hire agreement or hire -
purchase agreement concerned,  
and shall include, where appropriate, a potential “customer” and former 
“customer” within the meaning above;  
“financial abuse” means any of the following:  
(a) the wrongful or unauthorised taking, withholding, appropriation, 
or use of a customer’s money, assets or property;  
(b) any act or omission by a person, including through the use of a 
power of attorney, guardianship, or any other authority regarding 
a customer, to –  
(i) obtain control, through deception, intimidation or undue 
influence, over the customer’s money, assets or property, or  
(ii) wrongfully interfere with or deny the customer’s 
ownership, use, benefit or possession of the customer’s 
money, assets or property;  
“financial services ” include financial products ; 
“group” includes, unless otherwise specified, a company, its parent and its 
subsidiaries and any associated undertaking or related undertaking;  
4  [80] 
“high cost credit provider” and “high cost credit” have the meaning assigned to 
them in section 2 of the Consumer Credit Act 1995 (No. 24 of 1995);  
“key information” means any information which is likely to influence a 
customer’s actions with regard to a financial service;  
“MiFID Regulations 2017” means the European Union (Markets in Financial 
Instruments) Regulations 2017 (S.I. No. 375 of 2017);  
“person” means, unless otherwise specified, a natural person or a legal person;  
"regulated activities" means the provision of financial services that are provided 
in the State by a regulated entity and which are subject to the regulation of the 
Bank and a “regulated activity” is the provision of any one such financial service;  
“regulated entity” means a financial services provider authorised, registered or 
licensed by -   
(a) the Bank,  
(b) a state (other than the State) that is a member of the European 
Union,  or  
(c) a state (other than the State) that is a contracting party to the 
Agreement on the European Economic Area signed at Oporto on 
2 May 1992, as adjusted by all subsequent amendments to that 
agreement,  
that is providing regulated activities in the State;  
“unregulated activities” means the provision of services of a financial nature, 
which are not otherwise regulated activities, to consumers in the State.  
(2) For the purposes of the definition of “customer” in paragraph (1), 
“relevant borrower”, “credit servicing”, “credit agreement”, “consumer -hire 
agreement”, “hire -purchase agreement” and “hirer” have the same meaning as 
in Part V of the Central Bank Act 1997  (No. 8 of 1997).  
(3) Where a high cost credit provider is engaged in the activity of providing 
high cost credit, “consumer” means a consumer within the meaning of the 
Consumer Credit Act 1995.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").
detailed_results.gap_description: While the document addresses fitness and probity requirements, it does not explicitly address how the company will secure customers' interests as required by Regulation 5. The policy focuses on internal governance for fit and proper assessments but lacks specific provisions for ensuring the company's culture, strategy, business model, and decision-making take customers' interests into account. It also doesn't address how the company will act in accordance with customers' reasonable expectations, design financial services with customers' interests in mind, avoid exploiting customer behaviors, resolve complaints efficiently, handle errors, or deliver fair outcomes for customers.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: The Fit and Proper Policy should be expanded to include specific provisions that address how the fitness and probity requirements contribute to securing customers' interests. This should include: 1) Adding a section on how fit and proper assessments ensure that key personnel will act in customers' interests; 2) Incorporating customer-centric criteria in the fitness assessment; 3) Adding provisions about how the company's culture and decision-making processes take customers' interests into account; 4) Including requirements for resolving customer complaints and errors efficiently and fairly; 5) Adding provisions about designing financial services with customers' interests in mind; and 6) Establishing metrics to measure fair customer outcomes.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Securing customers' interests
detailed_results.regulation_text:
5. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(a), a regulated 
entity shall secure its customers’ interests, including by:  
(a) ensuring that its culture, strategy, business model, decision -
making, systems, controls, policies, processes and procedures 
take into account its customers’ interests;  
(b) acting in accordance with the reasonable expectations of its 
customers;  
(c) taking into account the interests of its customers when designing 
financial services, and the methods of delivery;  
(d) ensuring that its financial  services are not designed to unfairly 
exploit the behaviours, habits, preferences or biases of customers 
leading to customer detriment;  
(e) resolving any complaints received from customers efficiently, 
fairly and in a timely manner;  
(f) resolving errors and mistakes affecting customers efficiently, 
fairly and in a timely manner, and disclosing errors and mistakes 
to customers affected in a timely manner;  
(g) ensuring errors and mistakes identified for one customer that may 
reasonably have affected other customers are resolved for all 
affected customers efficiently, fairly and in a timely manner;  
(h) clearly distinguishing for customers between the entity’s 
regulated activities and its unregulated activities including by 
taking all appropriate steps to mitigate the risk that a customer 
6  [80] 
will understand an activity to be, or to carry the protections of, a 
regulated activity where this is not the case;  
(i) delivering fair outcomes for customers.
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.document_name: Saol InsureCo and HoldCo Fit and Proper Policy V6 approved 2025.pdf
detailed_results.compliance_evidence_with_page: [Page 3] Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").
detailed_results.gap_description: While the document acknowledges the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards and mentions acting with integrity in general terms, it does not explicitly address all elements of Regulation 6, particularly regarding: (a) operating without bias and managing conflicts of interest; (b) not exerting pressure on customers; and (c) not misusing assets or information of the entity or customers. The document focuses on fitness and probity of individuals but lacks specific provisions about how the entity itself will act with honesty and integrity in accordance with the 2025 Standards for Business regulations.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: 1. Update the policy to explicitly incorporate the requirements of Regulation 6 of the 2025 Standards for Business, including specific provisions about operating without bias, managing conflicts of interest, not exerting pressure on customers, and not misusing assets or information. 2. Add a dedicated section on how the entity will ensure compliance with the Standards for Business Regulations 2025, particularly regarding acting with honesty and integrity. 3. Include specific procedures for identifying and managing conflicts of interest at the entity level, not just at the individual level. 4. Develop clear guidelines on customer interactions to prevent undue pressure or influence. 5. Establish protocols for safeguarding customer and company assets and information.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Acting with honesty and integrity
detailed_results.regulation_text:
6. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(b), a regulated 
entity shall act honestly and with integrity, including by:  
(a) operating without bias and preventing, or identifying and 
appropriately managing, conflicts of interest;  
(b) not exerting pressure or influence on a customer so as to limit his 
or her ability to make an informed choice in relation to any 
financial service;  
(c) not misusing or misappropriating any assets or information of the 
regulated entity  or its customers.
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.document_name: Saol InsureCo and HoldCo Fit and Proper Policy V6 approved 2025.pdf

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Acting with due skill, care and diligence
detailed_results.regulation_text:
7. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(c), a regulated 
entity shall act with due skill, care and diligence, including by:  
(a) ensuring that persons who are responsible for managing the 
activities of the regulated entity have appropriate knowledge of 
the activities and associated risks that apply in the conduct of its 
affairs;  
(b) complying with all financial services legislation applicable to the 
conduct of its affairs;  
(c) operating in compliance with standards of market conduct and 
trading venue rules to which the regulated entity is subject by law 
and any market codes that apply to the affairs of the regulated 
entity.
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025

detailed_results.regulation_title: Financial abuse
detailed_results.regulation_text:
10. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(f), a regulated 
entity shall control and manage it affairs and systems to counter the risks of 
financial abuse to customers to whom it is providing financial services within 
the scope of its regulated activities, including by:  
(a) putting reasonable systems and controls in place in the context of 
the provision of its financial services, to mitigate the risk to its 
customers of financial abuse;  
(b) appropriately monitoring financial abuse trends relevant to its 
customers or the sector more generally;  
(c) carrying out ongoing monitoring in respect of potential 
vulnerabilities in the services and distribution channels, and 
ensuring appropriate escalation processes where there is 
increased risk to its customers of financial abuse;  
(d) notifying its customers through clear and timely communication 
of any digital frauds or deception connected to its affairs, or 
8  [80] 
specifically relevant to the sector in which the regulated entity is 
operating, and of which it is aware;  
(e) communicating the supports available to its customers, and the 
actions that customers can take in the event of financial abuse, 
directly connected to the regulated entity’s affairs.
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.document_name: Saol InsureCo and HoldCo Fit and Proper Policy V6 approved 2025.pdf

detailed_results.regulation_title: Controlling and managing its affairs
detailed_results.regulation_text:
11. Without prejudice to the generality of Regulation 4(1)(g), a regulated 
entity shall control and manage its affairs and systems sustainably, responsibly 
and in a sound and prudent manner, including by:  
(a) having and employing appropriate resources and implementing 
effective governance of  policies and procedures, systems and 
control checks, including compliance checks, to ensure that the 
regulated entity complies with its obligations under financial 
service s legislation;  
(b) providing appropriate staff training on the legal and regulatory 
framework relevant to the performance of those functions, 
including any legal obligations or standards that are imposed by 
or under financial services legislation;  
(c) ensuring that if delegating tasks, that those tasks are assigned to 
an appropriate person with effective oversight within the 
regulated entity;  
(d) managing its outsourced activities effectively to identify, monitor 
and manage its outsourcing risk;  
(e) arranging adequate protection for assets held by the regulated 
entity on behalf of a customer.
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK REFORM ACT 2010 (SECTION 17A) (STANDARDS FOR BUSINESS) REGULATIONS 2025

detailed_results.gap_description: While the document acknowledges the need to comply with Central Bank requirements and mentions fitness and probity standards, it lacks specific provisions for the disclosure and cooperation requirements outlined in Regulation 13, particularly regarding prompt notification to the Central Bank of matters such as suspected offenses, prescribed contraventions, or other issues the Bank would reasonably expect notice of. The document does not explicitly address the obligation to engage and cooperate with the Bank in good faith and without delay.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: Update the Fit and Proper Policy to include a dedicated section on disclosure and cooperation with the Central Bank that explicitly addresses the requirements of Regulation 13. This should include: 1) A clear procedure for promptly notifying the Central Bank of matters it would reasonably expect notice of (as listed in Regulation 13(a)); 2) Specific provisions for facilitating appropriate reporting to management and the Bank (as per Regulation 13(b)); 3) Guidelines for responding to requests and requirements in an open and timely manner; 4) Protocols to ensure non-destruction of records and avoidance of misleading information; 5) Procedures for ensuring attendance at meetings when required.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence:
Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").

Additionally, in accordance with the Act of 2010 and the Central Bank's Fitness and Probity Standards, Saol Assurance d.a.c. (the "Insurance Company") shall not permit a person to perform a Controlled Function ("CF"), including those to whom such a function may have been outsourced, unless it is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person complies with, has agreed to abide by the Fitness and Probity Standards and a certificate of compliance with standards of fitness and probity, issued by the Insurance Company, is in force in relation to that person.
detailed_results.gap_description: The document focuses on fitness and probity requirements for persons performing controlled functions but does not specifically address the requirements of Regulation 20 regarding to whom fees, commissions, rewards or remuneration may be paid in respect of regulated activities. There is no explicit mention of the restrictions on paying commissions or fees only to the categories of persons listed in Regulation 20.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: The Fit and Proper Policy should be updated to include specific provisions addressing Regulation 20 of the Consumer Protection Regulations 2025. This should include explicit statements that the company will only pay fees, commissions, rewards or remuneration to the categories of persons permitted under Regulation 20, and outline procedures to verify that recipients of such payments fall within the permitted categories. The policy should also include monitoring and compliance verification processes specific to this requirement.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Fees, commissions, rewards (etc.) permitted to be paid or provided to certain persons only
detailed_results.regulation_text: 20. A regulated entity may pay or provide a fee, commission, other reward or remuneration in respect of the provision of regulated activities only to a person that is any of the following: (a) a regulated entity; (b) a certified person; (c) an individual for whom a regulated entity has taken full and unconditional responsibility under the Investment Intermediaries Act 1995; (d) an agent, branch or entity to which activities are outsourced in accordance with the European Union (Payment Services) Regulations 2018 (S.I. No. 6 of 2018) where the regulated entity remains fully liable for the acts of that agent, branch or entity to which activities are outsourced; (e) a distributor, agent, branch or entity to which activities are outsourced in accordance with the European Communities (Electronic Money) Regulations 2011 where the regulated entity remains fully liable for the acts of that distributor, agent, branch or entity to which activities are outsourced; (f) a person that is specifically exempted by law from a requirement to hold an authorisation, licence or registration to carry out the regulated activity in respect of which the fee, commission, other reward or remuneration is paid; (g) a credit intermediary within the meaning of the Act of 1995 and the European Communities (Consumer Credit Agreements) Regulations 2010; (h) a person that is no longer providing a regulated activity, but the fee, commission, other reward or remuneration is paid in respect of a regulated activity that the person provided when the person was a person referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (g ). 42 [81]

detailed_results.regulation_title: No specified level of consumer business to be required of intermediary in order to retain appointment
detailed_results.regulation_text: 25. (1) A regulated entity shall not require an intermediary to provide a specified level of business from consumers in order to retain an appointment from that regulated entity. (2) This Regulation applies only to a regulated entity that distributes its products to consumers through an intermediary. 44 [81]

detailed_results.regulation_title: Product producers - commission paid to intermediary based on levels of business provided
detailed_results.regulation_text: 26. (1) This Regulation applies to a product producer that distributes its products to consumers through an intermediary and pays commission to an intermediary based on levels of business provided by that intermediary. (2) A product producer shall ensure that the arrangements referred to in paragraph (1) - (a) do not impair the intermediary's duty to act in the best interests of consumers, and (b) do not give rise to a conflict of interest between the intermediary and a consumer.

detailed_results.compliance_evidence: Under Solvency II insurance undertakings and insurance holding companies are required to ensure that all persons who effectively run, or have other key functions within, an insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company are fit and proper to perform their duties and have regard to any code setting out standards of fitness and probity issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the "Central Bank") under section 50 of the Central Bank Reform Act, 2010 ("Act of 2010").
detailed_results.gap_description: The document focuses on fitness and probity standards for individuals in controlled functions but does not specifically address employee remuneration arrangements that could lead to conflicts with consumer best interests or suitability requirements as required by Regulation 27. While the document mentions compliance with Central Bank regulations, it lacks explicit provisions regarding how remuneration structures are designed to avoid incentivizing inappropriate consumer recommendations.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations:
1. Add a specific section addressing remuneration arrangements and how they are structured to ensure alignment with consumer best interests.
2. Include explicit provisions prohibiting remuneration structures that could incentivize employees to recommend unsuitable financial services.
3. Incorporate references to Regulation 27 of the Consumer Protection Regulations 2025 in the 'Schedule of applicable regulatory requirements' in Appendix 3.
4. Establish monitoring mechanisms to ensure remuneration practices do not conflict with suitability requirements.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Conditions for employee remuneration arrangements
detailed_results.regulation_text: 27. (1) A regulated entity shall not structure its remuneration arrangements with employees such that they could result in employees providing, arranging or recommending a financial service to a consumer in a manner that may be inconsistent with the regulated enti ty's obligations - (a) to act in the best interests of consumers, and (b) to satisfy suitability requirements. (2) In this Regulation, "suitability requirements" has the meaning given to it in Regulation 21(2).
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025

detailed_results.gap_description: While the document establishes a Fit and Proper Policy and references compliance with Central Bank regulations, it does not specifically address the requirement in Regulation 29 regarding gifts and rewards that might create conflicts of interest with consumers. The document lacks explicit provisions for ensuring officers or employees do not offer, give, solicit or accept gifts or rewards that could conflict with duties toward consumers.
detailed_results.gap_recommendations: The Fit and Proper Policy should be updated to include a specific section on gifts and rewards that: 1) Explicitly prohibits offering, giving, soliciting or accepting gifts or rewards that could create conflicts with duties toward consumers; 2) Establishes procedures for identifying and managing potential conflicts arising from gifts; 3) Implements a gifts and rewards register; 4) Creates a review process for gifts above certain thresholds; and 5) Includes this topic in regular training for all staff and officers.
detailed_results.regulation_title: Offering, giving, accepting (etc.) gifts or rewards not to create conflict of interest
detailed_results.regulation_text: 29. Subject to Regulation 23, a regulated entity shall take reasonable steps to ensure that it or any of its officers or employees do not offer, give, solicit or accept any gifts or rewards, monetary or otherwise, likely to conflict with any duty of the regula ted entity towards consumers or any duty of the recipient officer or employee towards consumers in relation to his or her activities in the regulated entity.
